Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: They notice minor inconsistencies in a building plan that are unlikely to cause immediate issues.
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, clipboard in hand, eyes darting between my stepbrother tightening his helmet and the building plans I’d brought to review. He grinned at me, board in hand, ready to launch himself down the steep, cracked ramp. “Watch this!” he called. My heart thudded. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, to keep him safe, but he hated when I hovered. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from my boss, reminding me to double-check the plans for the new community center. I’d already noticed a few minor inconsistencies—nothing that would cause immediate danger, but as an architect, I was expected to ensure every detail was perfect, every risk accounted for. My mind raced, torn between running to stop my brother before he hurt himself and sitting down to pore over the plans before the deadline. Both roles demanded my vigilance, my care, but I couldn’t be in two places at once. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing in, my hands trembling as I tried to decide where my responsibility truly lay.
